text: Hello! Has anyone tried to change the system time in robolectric tests?

<@U0QR1SM32>: Ok so I ran the following code inside a test
```
ShadowSystemClock.setCurrentTimeMillis(0);
System.out.println(new Date());
System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis());
System.out.println(Calendar.getInstance().getTimeInMillis());
```
It still gives me todays date.

Has anyone else run into trouble using

```TabLayout.Tab.setCustomView()```

?
The custom view doesn't seem to be attaching to the tab. I've stepped through the source for TabLayout and nothing stands out to me.
but i set all things via style.
It's more the fact that I need something like this
<@U108U1P9V|lukewilliamduncan> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/lukewilliamduncan/F1F3DSR36/pasted_image_at_2016_06_08_01_28_pm.png|Pasted image at 2016-06-08, 1:28 PM>
But I don't think that'll be possible via style.
Stepping through again, it looks like the custom views are being cleared for some reason. I can't even extend the class as it's private.
TabLayout doesn't allow the use of setText and setIcon at the same time?
you can set the icon, but it sits beside the text and not on top
Obviously this is a material design decision, but it's still irking me

attachments.title: Tabs - Components - Google design guidelines
attachments.fallback: Google design guidelines: Tabs - Components - Google design guidelines

text: It shows what you want to achieve so that's odd

:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/design/widget/TabLayout.Tab.html|TabLayout.Tab>*: _public static final class TabLayout. ... Return the icon associated with this tab. ....  Similarly, if this layout contains an ImageView with ID icon then it will be updated  ..._
:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/design/widget/TabLayout.html|TabLayout>*: _Population of the tabs to display is done through TabLayout.Tab instances. You  create tabs via newTab() . From there you can change the tab's label or icon via ..._
:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/studio/write/vector-asset-studio.html|Add Multi-Density Vector Graphics | Android Studio>*: _Android Studio includes a tool called Vector Asset Studio that helps you add  material icons and import Scalable Vector Graphic (SVG) files into your project as  ..._
Hmm. There's maybe more to it :slightly_smiling_face: Problem might be though, the images above the text in my design are actually user's profile images.
I guess it’s a case of google not doing what google says

hey guys what do you think about clean architecture? Is it just only true way ?

attachments.title: The Clean Architecture | 8th Light
attachments.text: Over the last several years we’ve seen a whole range of ideas regarding the architecture of systems. These include: Hexagonal Architecture (a.k.a. Ports and Adapters) by Alistair Cockburn and adopted by Steve Freeman, and Nat...

text: of course it's good way, but too many abscration layers
i mean the best answer is to use what makes sense for your needs
if you are making a one off app that has few features.. you probably dont need a whole lot of architecture
yeah agree too many architect.. use which you think fits you..

Rx question: I have a repository that includes a memory, disk and network „bucket“ to get data from. I can subscribe to an observable that will will give me always the „best“ data. That works fine.
Now I have a ViewPager with 4 fragments. All 4 fragments access the same data and just filter by different criteria.
Obviously if I just create new Observables for each fragment, they will do all the work (memory->disk->network) 4 times.
So what I want is to have the Observable do the work only once and still get the data into all 4 fragments.

I looked into `share()`, but I would need to keep track of the subscribers. Would it be an alternative to let the Activity subscribe to the observable and hand the data through to the Fragments somehow?

I’ll look into it. I just tried using `cache()` and it seems the network request was done only once now but all 4 fragments got the correct data. Now I need to check if that fucks with my repository’s caching rules
all fragments subscribe to the subject. Your repository will push anything into the subject whenever its ready and the subject will emit those through to the fragments.
yeah, using `cache()` will override my own caching
